    Assessment of missing cell-level metadata in single cell GEO records

    Rui Fu

    RNA Bioscience Initative, University of Colorado School of Medicine

    2022-01-01

    get_geo.Rmd

    Current GEO query used: 

    "expression profiling by high throughput sequencing" AND
("single nuclei" OR "single cell" OR "scRNAseq" OR "scRNA-seq" OR "snRNAseq" OR "snRNA-seq")
    #> [1] "010122"
#> Response [https://eutils.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/eutils/efetch.fcgi?db=gds&query_key=1&WebEnv=MCID_61cfafc7f966a36f90423c81]

    Parse GEO query

    Total entries: 7366

    Number of entries filtered out because key words were not found: 876

    Merged super and subseries: 580

    The fraction of GEO entries with potential metadata (file with “meta”, “annot”, “clustering”, “colData”, or “type” in filename or rda/rds/rdata/h5ad/loom files) is 0.1717675. Note however that these terms include some false positives (such as gene annotation file, patient metadata, and phenotype table), which we manually inspected and corrected (false positive fraction at 0.0525394). Final fraction: 0.1681568

    Comparison of parsed data to database from Svensson et al.

    Overlap of scRNA-seq GEO entries between manual curation and the GEO query is 0.9657534. Number of entries not public: 0. Fraction with metadata: 0.2151515.

    GEO cell-level metadata availability by journal

    Potential effects of GEO cell-level metadata on data reuse and citations

    Investigation of whether metadata deposition is better in projects with authors developing scRNA-seq informatic tools (split out to “upload author/other author/not”, or just “author/not”)
